info.headline: Flood Warning issued January 09 at 12:33PM EST until January 10 at 10:45AM EST by NWS Greenville-Spartanburg
info.description: ...The National Weather Service in Greenville-Spartanburg SC has issued a Flood Warning for the following rivers in North Carolina... Pigeon River At Canton affecting Haywood County. .Minor flooding along the Pigeon River from Max Thompson Rd to Canton and downstream towards Clyde is expected to develop over the next several hours as the upstream floodwave from the east and west forks of the Pigeon River works its way downstream. The Pigeon River forks are beginning to crest and it will take 2-4 hours for the Pigeon River near Canton to crest. Heavy rain has ended across the area. ...FLOOD WARNING IN EFFECT UNTIL LATE TOMORROW MORNING... ...REPLACES RIVER FLOOD ADVISORY... * WHAT...Minor flooding is forecast. * WHERE...Pigeon River at Canton. * WHEN...Until late tomorrow morning. * IMPACTS...At 10.0 feet, Water may approach the yards of some homes on and near Fiberville Road. At 11.0 feet, The river will overflow its banks and start to flood low-lying areas and some secondary roadways from Canton to Clyde. At 12.0 feet, At this level floodwaters may be approaching paper mill property. Areas on the right bank of the river near Canton will begin to flood. This may include residential yards on Fiberville Road and parts of Valley, North, and Conley Streets. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 12:15 PM EST Tuesday the stage was 8.9 feet and rising rapidly. - Forecast...The river is expected to crest near 11.0 feet this afternoon. It will then fall below Minor Flood Stage late this evening. A rise to near 12 feet is possible. - Minor Flood Stage is 10.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood &&
info.instruction: Motorists should not attempt to drive around barricades or drive cars through flooded areas. To escape rising water, take the shortest path to higher ground. Even 6 inches of fast-moving flood water can knock you off your feet and a depth of 2 feet will float your car. Never try to walk, swim, or drive through such swift water. If you come upon flood waters, stop, turn around and go another way. For detailed information including observed and forecast stages, flood impacts, flood history, FEMA Flood Hazard Layers, and more, please visit: https://water.weather.gov/ahps2/index.php?wfo=gsp The next statement will be issued beforeWednesday morning at 1015 AM EST.
